Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 06:09PM lexi4 wrote: Janis, I left work after my IBC diagnosis. I had pretty much always worked in the dental field up until I was diagnosed. It was tough at first. I had a lot of guilty feelings for not going back, but my husband was 100% behind the decision. I just recently started working in my kids school district. It actually works out great. It is a couple of hours a day and when they are off I am too. It isn't as much $, but it's a little extra and gets me out of the house working a stress free job. Whatever you decide is the right choice for you and your family. ( I'd love to see you at home full time with your boys). Lexi

Posts.Title: Still Ned roxy42 Rhonda1966

Posts.Content: lexi4 wrote: from surgery on Aug. 30th. It's hard to believe it has been 5years already. I still deal with fatigue daily and have some aches and pains, but overall, life is great! My sweet boy was in the 8th grade when I was diagnosed. Guess what!? He is leaving for college next week!! I made it!! That was a prayer of mine when I was diagnosed. To see my children through their high school years. My dear daughter is a freshman and I still pray nightly to see her through, too. I couldn't have gotten through this nearly as well without all of you. You were my lifelineÂ when I was scared out of my mind. I always new that coming here was where I could share my fears as I didn't want to burden my family with them.Â And they were always met with prayers and cyber-hugs. I pray for us all each night to this day. I am hopeful to be celebrating many more years with ALL of you.Thanks for all you do! Hugs and Prayers, LexiÂ  Dx 8/22/2005, IBC, 3cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 3, 5/6 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 5 years out lexi4 stacys_mom

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2016 09:20PM lexi4 wrote: Hello stage III sisters! Checking in as my 11 year cancerversary is coming up at the end of the month. I still see my oncologist every 6 mos. Have minor aches and pains, but feel good for the most part :)  My son, who was 13 when I was diagnosed, was married this past April. He is 24 and a great son! My daughter, was 9 at the time of my diagnosis, is now 20 and a junior in college. I feel blessed and fortunate to have been able to reach these milestones! Also, celebrated my 25th wedding anniversary with my sweet sweet husband. I am very happy to come back to BCO and share my milestones. This site was a lifesaver for me! Shoutout to all of my stage III sisters! I continue to pray for us and am so hopeful that a cure/ vaccine is close . Hugs and Prayers, Lexi

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2018 04:05PM lexi4 wrote: Hello stage III friends. Just checking in. I’ve celebrated my 13th cancerversary I had a horrible prognosis but thanks to my Oncs and the. Modern medicines, I’m still here :) My kids were in grade 4 and 8 when i was diagnosed. Ive been there for my oldest’s wedding and my yougest’s college graduation. I feel very thankful and blessed to be here. I am also thankful to BC.ORG and my stage III friends who helped me get through frightening times. I’m so happy to see familiar names of those who were here before me, sharing updates and cheering us all on. I feel sad to see all the new members to our unfortunate club. But, theres hope. I dont post often but check in now and then. I pray for us all daily. Hang in there. One day at a time. Hugs and Prayers, Lex

Posts.Title: Got some great news! Annie62 pupfoster1

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 02:58AM lexi4 wrote: Hi Stage III Sisters, I am still NED, as far as I know. I still see my onc every 4 mos and have an appt to see her this week. Life has been a bit crazy here at home. My dear daddy has been in the hospital for weeks fighting for his life. He has a number of issues going on physically that we are hoping and praying he will recover from. We welcome any and all prayers for healing and recovery for my dear poppa. My kids are great. My DS is graduating HS in 2010. I never thought I'd be here to see this! I am so proud and excited for him. We will be getting college apps filled out here soon. My DD is in 8th grade and is a terrific student and has a great circle of friends. We are so thankful that our kids have survived and thrived through my getting sick. They are sweet compassionate kids. I am in the finishing stages of my foobie recon. I will be having tattoos to finish up the nipp recon. It doesn't make me forget what I went through, but gosh they look really good considering! Nice for wearing clothes and not using the prosthetic foobie. That is it it in a nutshell. I am sad to see new faces in our club all the time. I hope that I can be helpful and encourage others through this horrible experience. There is light at the end of the tunnel. Hugs, Lexi
